node.title: Eden Deering Started Her Art Career at 8
node.alt: Eden Deering curates exhibitions that comment on social life. “All of my friends are artists,” she said. “It is why I am.”
node.description: She is the director of PPOW, a venerable art gallery in TriBeCa co-founded by her mother in 1983.
node.content: ["Name: Eden Deering", "Age: 30", "Hometown: New York City", "Now Lives: In a one-bedroom apartment in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn that she shares with her boyfriend, Weston Lowe, who also runs a gallery.", "Claim to Fame: Ms. Deering is a director at PPOW, a contemporary art gallery in TriBeCa that grew out of the 1980s East Village art scene. She curates book-fueled exhibitions that comment on social life. \u201cEverything, for me, starts with reading,\u201d Ms. Deering said. \u201cWriters and artists have always been in conversation with each other. Books give me a tool to think about the importance of art.\u201d Her first group exhibition in 2019, \u201cDo You Love Me?,\u201d focused on \u201cthe unbalanced power dynamic between those that desire love and those in our culture who have the power to give it,\u201d she said.", "Big Break: Ms. Deering unofficially began her art world internship at age 8, when her mother, Wendy Olsoff, one of PPOW\u2019s founders, took her to Art Basel in Switzerland, the Venice Biennale in Italy, and various artists\u2019 studios. In 2016, while working as an assistant at Gladstone Gallery, she started a roving art collective, Duplex, with Sydney Fishman. Duplex now has a permanent gallery on Essex Street in Lower Manhattan. \u201cAll of my friends are artists,\u201d she said. \u201cIt is why I am.\u201d", "Latest Project: Ms. Deering will lead the programming at PPOW\u2019s second downtown gallery, opening later this year a block away. It\u2019s \u201ca space for experimentation,\u201d she said. \u201cWe don\u2019t always get to work with the artists that I bring in for group shows.\u201d", "Next Thing: PPOW\u2019s summer 2022 exhibition will feature feminist landscape paintings, including works by Carolee Schneemann, women artists in their 20s, as well as some from the 19th century. \u201cCarolee always said she was a painter,\u201d Ms. Deering said. \u201cThe general culture does not think of her as one.\u201d", "Personal Space: Her mother and Penny Pilkington, who co-founded PPOW in 1983, are still involved with the gallery. \u201cI feel very honored to work for such incredible women,\u201d Ms. Deering said. She credits the co-founders for their clarity of purpose. \u201cArtists need money and space to work,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd that\u2019s always been Wendy and Penny\u2019s No. 1 priority.\u201d"]
